image.altText: A young girl with dark black hair, wearing jeans and a denim jacket, sits cross legged and smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: Tarikjot Singh, who abducted his ex-girlfriend Jasmeen Kaur from her Adelaide workplace and then buried her alive in the Flinders Ranges, is jailed for the murder, with the sentencing judge saying he could not find words to describe the young woman's final moments.

title.children: Man jailed for 'horrific' murder of ex-girlfriend Jasmeen Kaur in outback SA

image.altText: An aerial view of houses in Hobart, Tasmania.

items.synopsis: The RBA has left interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent. It leaves the cash rate at its highest level since April 2012. Follow live.

title.children: RBA warns another rate hike may be on the cards despite holding off in August

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: RBA governor Philip Lowe used his statement to note that services inflation is going to be a key focus for the central bank going forward, and noting that it's been "surprisingly persistent" overseas — and is concerned the same might occur here. So what is services inflation, and why is the RBA concerned about it? It's simply referring to how much the prices of services (think hairdressing, vet services, insurance) are rising — and last week's inflation data from the ABS showed that services inflation was gathering pace while goods inflation was falling. You can see the divergence between the two below: The ABS said inflation in the prices for services recorded its largest annual rise since 2001, driven by higher prices in a range of services categories including rents, restaurant meals, holiday travel and insurance. Services inflation is now running at 6.3%, up from 6.1% in the March quarter. So it's still heading higher, but g oods inflation is definitely heading down — it's at 5.8%, down from 7.6% in March.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Briskly' rising services inflation a key focus for the RBA going forward

children.content: RBA governor Philip Lowe used his statement to note that services inflation is going to be a key focus for the central bank going forward, and noting that it's been "surprisingly persistent" overseas — and is concerned the same might occur here.
So what is services inflation, and why is the RBA concerned about it?
It's simply referring to how much the prices of services (think hairdressing, vet services, insurance) are rising — and last week's inflation data from the ABS showed that
services inflation was gathering pace while goods inflation was falling.
You can see the divergence between the two below:
The ABS said
inflation in the prices for services recorded its largest annual rise since 2001
, driven by higher prices in a range of services categories
including rents, restaurant meals, holiday travel and insurance.
Services inflation is now running at 6.3%
, up from 6.1% in the March quarter.
So it's still heading higher, but g
oods inflation is definitely heading down
— it's at 5.8%, down from 7.6% in March.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Borrowers can breath a sigh of relief this month, but will the RBA raise interest rates again? Governor Philip Lowe said in his statement that it may be necessary as inflation is still running at 6 per cent annually, which is well above the RBA's 2 to 3 per cent range. Betashares chief economist David Bassinese is expecting one more interest rate rise later this year. "The RBA’s decision to keep rates on hold is a just reward for an economy showing tentative signs of solving its inflation problem without needing to go into recession." "With medium term inflation expectations still contained as well as ongoing downside risks to consumer spending, the RBA can afford to give the economy the benefit of the doubt for at least a little while longer. " Mr Bassinese says the RBA should take heart from the signs of slowing services inflation (eg the cost of electricity). "There's a good chance we’ve seen the last rate increase this cycle." "My base case, however, is sufficient resilience in consumer spending in the coming months will see the RBA raise rates one last time in November." Capital Economic's Australia and New Zealand economist Abhijit Surya says most market economists expected the central bank to raise rates by 0.25 per cent today. "The RBA's decision to leave its cash rate unchanged at 4.1 per cent means that its almost certain that our forecast for a terminal rate of 4.6 per cent won't come to fruition." Mr Surya notes that the RBA now predicts inflation won't come back to its target range of 2 to 3 per cent until the end of 2025, instead of mid-2025. "However, barring any new inflationary shocks, there's a good chance the RBA is done tightening altogether." But he doesn't see any rate cuts, if any, until next year because of high services inflation and the strong employment market.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will the RBA raise rates again?

children.content: Borrowers can breath a sigh of relief this month,
but will the RBA raise interest rates again?
Governor Philip Lowe said in his statement that it may be necessary as inflation is still running at 6 per cent annually, which is well above the RBA's 2 to 3 per cent range.
Betashares chief economist David Bassinese is expecting one more interest rate rise later this year.
"The RBA’s decision to keep rates on hold is a just reward for an economy showing tentative signs of solving its inflation problem without needing to go into recession."

"With medium term inflation expectations still contained as well as ongoing downside risks to consumer spending, the RBA can afford to give the economy the benefit of the doubt for at least a little while longer.
Mr Bassinese says the RBA should take heart from the signs of slowing services inflation (eg the cost of electricity).
"There's a good chance we’ve seen the last rate increase this cycle."
"My base case, however, is sufficient resilience in consumer spending in the coming months will see the RBA raise rates one last time in November."
Capital Economic's Australia and New Zealand economist Abhijit Surya says most market economists expected the central bank to raise rates by 0.25 per cent today.
"The RBA's decision to leave its cash rate unchanged at 4.1 per cent means that its almost certain that our forecast for a terminal rate of 4.6 per cent won't come to fruition."
Mr Surya notes that the RBA now predicts inflation won't come back to its target range of 2 to 3 per cent until the end of 2025, instead of mid-2025.
"However, barring any new inflationary shocks, there's a good chance the RBA is done tightening altogether."
But he doesn't see any rate cuts, if any, until next year because of high services inflation and the strong employment market.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's some reaction to the RBA's decision to keep interest rates on hold for the second month in a row. PropTrack Senior Economist Eleanor Creagh says slowing inflation is behind the pause in interest rate rises by the RBA. “Subsiding momentum in inflation and consumer spending has eased the pressure on the RBA to continue lifting interest rates, allowing more time to assess the economic outlook as it tries to engineer a soft landing while returning inflation to target." "Though still high relative to history, and well above the RBA’s 2-3 per cent target range, CPI inflation was below both market expectations and the RBA’s official forecasts and looks set to continue to moderate and move lower into the first half of 2024.” But Mortgage Choice chief executive Anthony Waldron points out that banks are still increasing mortgage rates despite the RBA staying on hold last month. “Borrowers will be pleased to see that the Reserve Bank has held the cash rate steady for the second month running; however, a stable cash rate in July didn’t stop the nation’s lenders from lifting rates on some fixed- and variable-rate home loan products.”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA rates on hold reaction

children.content: Here's some reaction to the RBA's decision to keep interest rates on hold for the second month in a row.
PropTrack Senior Economist Eleanor Creagh says slowing inflation is behind the pause in interest rate rises by the RBA.

“Subsiding momentum in inflation and consumer spending has eased the pressure on the RBA to continue lifting interest rates, allowing more time to assess the economic outlook as it tries to engineer a soft landing while returning inflation to target."

"Though still high relative to history, and well above the RBA’s 2-3 per cent target range, CPI inflation was below both market expectations and the RBA’s official forecasts and looks set to continue to moderate and move lower into the first half of 2024.”
But Mortgage Choice chief executive Anthony Waldron points out that banks are still increasing mortgage rates despite the RBA staying on hold last month.

“Borrowers will be pleased to see that the Reserve Bank has held the cash rate steady for the second month running; however, a stable cash rate in July didn’t stop the nation’s lenders from lifting rates on some fixed- and variable-rate home loan products.”

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank has left interest rates on hold for the second month in a row for the first time since it started raising them in May last year. The RBA's cash rate target will remain at 4.1 per cent following today's board meeting. You can read more about what that means on our business blog.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Reserve Bank leaves cash rate on hold at 4.1 per cent

featuredLink.title: Live: RBA leaves interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent

children.content: The Reserve Bank has left interest rates on hold for the second month in a row for the first time since it started raising them in May last year.
The RBA's cash rate target will remain at 4.1 per cent following today's board meeting.
You can read more about what that means on our business blog.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reuters news agency reports that Russian anti-aircraft units have downed drones in Moscow today, but officials say one drone, allegedly sent out of control by anti-aircraft activity, hit the same high-rise tower that was impacted earlier this week. Moscow Mayor Sergei Sobyanin says the tower at Moskva Citi has been damaged, with "glazing destroyed over 150 square metres". No injuries have been reported. You can read more on this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Another drone has hit a Moscow high-rise tower

featuredLink.title: Moscow mayor accuses Ukraine of drone strike on city buildings

props.alt: A close up of exterior glass windows of a skyscrapper wich have been badly damaged on a small number of floors

children.content: (Reuters: Evgenia Novozhenina)
The Reuters news agency reports that Russian anti-aircraft units have downed drones in Moscow today, but officials say one drone, allegedly sent out of control by anti-aircraft activity,
hit the same high-rise tower that was impacted earlier this week
Moscow Mayor Sergei Sobyanin says the tower at Moskva Citi has been damaged, with "glazing destroyed over 150 square metres".
No injuries have been reported.
You can read more on this story here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Queensland Police Service Acting Assistant Commissioner Col Briggs says today's announcement comes after years of investigations. "From the moment [Operation] Argos located images of victim children being shared on the dark web in 2014, an extensive examination was launched to identify the children in the pictures," he says. "The challenges posed by an investigation of this type were significant and officers never gave up on identifying this alleged offender, reminding themselves that everything you do online leaves a trace."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Police say images shared on the dark web in 2014 led to their investigation

children.content: Queensland Police Service Acting Assistant Commissioner Col Briggs says today's announcement comes after years of investigations.
"From the moment [Operation] Argos located images of victim children being shared on the dark web in 2014, an extensive examination was launched to identify the children in the pictures," he says.

"The challenges posed by an investigation of this type were significant and officers never gave up on identifying this alleged offender, reminding themselves that everything you do online leaves a trace."
